Abstract:
Probabilistic electricity price forecasting (PEPF) is gaining increasing interest due to the need for accurate uncertainty quantification to support the operation in complex power markets with a growing share of renewable generation. Distributional neural networks ensembles (DE) have been shown to outperform state-of-the-art PEPF benchmarks. However, they require reliability improvements, as they fail to pass coverage tests at various steps on the prediction horizon. In this work, we address this issue by extending the DE framework with a Conformal Prediction-based technique.

Introduction:
Trustworthy day-ahead electricity price forecasting (EPF) systems are crucial for effective operation in modern power markets. EPF is used by companies to anticipate price movements and perform bidding strategies, and it is a key enabler of high-stakes decision-making stages, such as optimal generation management and energy-aware planning and scheduling. EPF is a complex task with peculiar characteristics, including latent non-linear relationships to conditioning variables, meshed short and long-term seasonalities, and high volatility. Over the years, various approaches have been investigated to perform EPF, from traditional statistical models to machine learning techniques. An increasing research interest is being devoted to neural network-based probabilistic EPF (PEPF), which aims to characterize the underlying model uncertainty in the target space. This is essential for supporting the operation in electricity markets with increasing volatility.

Critical deviations have been introduced by the repercussions of steep gas price variations on power plants. The increasing penetration of renewable sources in the generation mix is introducing further short-term price fluctuations. Additional variables, such as CO2 certificate prices, interact with power price features. Ensembles of distributional NNs (i.e., Deep Ensembles) parameterizing flexible Johnson's SU distributions have been proposed for this purpose, outperforming state-of-the-art PEPF benchmarks. Despite their significant performances, such models still require calibration improvements, as they fail to pass coverage tests at various hours on the prediction horizon.

In this work, we aim to tackle this open issue by extending the Deep Ensembles framework with a Conformal Prediction (CP) based technique. We target the approximation of the feature-conditioned day-ahead prices distribution through a discrete set of quantiles (e.g., deciles), coupled in prediction intervals (PIs) of increasing coverage degree around the median. We leverage the asymmetric CP formulation proposed by (Romano et al., 2019) for regression tasks, developed through a daily recalibrated multi-horizon time series setup.

Methods:
The proposed PEPF approach consists of the following major ingredients. Each ensemble component is designed to provide day-ahead price predictions over the whole horizon h∈ {t+1,..., t+H} given the input conditioning set xt at time t. The latter can involve both past values of the target series and a set of exogenous variables. We employ feed-forward maps (labelled DNN hereafter), leaving a further investigation of alternative architectures for future extensions. To estimate the conditional quantiles to be calibrated, we exploit both a quantile regression setup and samples from distributional NNs.
